## Overview

Hexagonal grids with R. We use the {sf} package. 

Load Libraries
```{r}
library(sf)
library(rnaturalearth)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(stringr)

```

2. Get Italy boundaries
```{r}
# Natural Earth country boundaries
world <- rnaturalearth::ne_countries(scale = 10, returnclass = "sf")

italy <- world %>% 
  filter(admin == "Italy") %>% 
  st_transform(3857)   # good for equal-area cell grids


```

3. Create hexagonal grid (~200 km)

In EPSG:3857, metres are units → 200,000 m ≈ 200 km

square = FALSE gives hexagons
```{r}
cell <- st_make_grid(
  italy,
  cellsize = 200000,    # ~200 km
  what = "polygons",
  square = FALSE         # hexagons
)

cell_sf <- st_sf(geometry = cell)

```

4. Clip hexagons to Italy
```{r}
hex_it <- st_intersection(cell_sf, italy)


```


```{r}
library(showtext)
font_add_google(name = 'Roboto Condensed', 
                family = 'Roboto Condensed')
showtext_auto()
showtext_opts(dpi = 300)
```


5. Plot hexagonal grid over Italy
```{r}
ggplot() +
  geom_sf(data = hex_it, fill = "#7781a6", color = "white") +
  geom_sf(data = italy, fill = NA, color = "black", size = 0.5) +
  ggthemes::theme_map() +
  labs(
    title = "Hexagonal Grid over Italy",
    subtitle = "Approximate cell size: 200 km",
    caption = "#30DayMapChallenge 2025 | Day 25: Hexagons\nData source: Natural Earth | Map by Federica Gazzelloni"
  ) +
  ggthemes::theme_map()+
  theme(text=element_text(color="white",
                          family="Roboto Condensed",face="bold"),
        plot.title = element_text(size = 18),
        plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 12),
        plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.5))
```
